qas.question: When did Richard Price give a sermon to the Revolution Society?
What was the Revolution Society commemorating?
Who did Price think should see themselves as citizens of the world?

plausible_answers.text: A Discourse on the Love of our Country, to the Revolution Society

qas.question: What was the name of Burke's sermon?
When was the Revolution Society founded?
How did Burke say Englishmen should see themselves?
When did Burke propose the idea of universal rights for men?
When did Price read Burke's sermon?

context: In <b7_0>January 1790<b7_0/>, Burke read Dr. Richard Price's sermon of <a0_0><b8_0>4 November 1789<b8_0/><a0_0/> entitled, <b4_0>A Discourse on the Love of our Country, to the Revolution Society<b4_0/>. That society had been founded to commemorate <a1_0>the Glorious Revolution of <b5_0>1688<b5_0/><a1_0/>. In this sermon Price espoused the philosophy of <a3_0>universal "Rights of Men"<a3_0/>. Price argued that love of our country "does not imply any conviction of the superior value of it to other countries, or any particular preference of its laws and constitution of government". Instead, Price asserted that <a2_0>Englishmen<a2_0/> should see themselves "more <b6_0>as citizens of the world<b6_0/> than as members of any particular community".
